 I believe individuals always act in order to maximize their own percieved "good" in any give situation. Good and bad can be expressed in economic terms as gains and costs. Most choices will result in both 
 gains and costs elements as well as carry opportunity costs (the net-gain/cost that could have achieved by making the opposite choice). I do believe that individuals always use these mechanics subconsiously or concoiusly when making a choice. The issue is not wether this applies to individuals IMO, but rather how to quantify the "good" and "bad" for individual choices.
 
 The model I tried to apply to the jail situation deals with the mechanics of making choices and how individuals maximize good with a budget constraint. In the jail case, the good is economic benefit and the cost is the risk of getting caught and punishment. The budget constraint can be virtually anything that constrain the choices of the individual. In the jail case, the constraint is time. The opportunity cost is the net-gain from honest work.
 
 
 If you get caught, it's over. In economics, the more you sell the more you make. In this scenario, the more you commit the more of a chance of getting caught. 

 
 Economics is more than just sales. It`s also (among other things) about explaining choices and actions of humans who are constrained by various factors (budget). 
 
 I agree that the more crime you commit the more of a risk of getting caught. However, this is a part of the cost of carrying out the action and it should be used to detract from the gain from commiting the crime.
 
 
I can see where they may just commit the crime anyway despite the punishment and keep the crime rate the same, but for the crime rate to rise when the punishment goes up is rediculous in my opinion. 

 
 Lets try an analogy. 
 
 If you where to make 10 dollars/hour at your current job and work 8 hours a day, you would make 80 dollars/day. If the government where to put a 10% tax on your paycheck, your earnings would be 70 dollars/day. Would you still work 8 hours? Or would you work more? Or perhaps work less? I can`t answer for you because I don`t know your preferences. Some would probably work less in this scenario as they would value one hour of leisure time more than they would value 9 dollars. Others would work more as they would try to compensate this loss in earnings. Others would work the same ammount of hours.
 
 In economic theory, this is often called the "income effect" and "substitution effect". The income effect makes the individual work more if their earnings are lowered as they try to compensate fot the loss, alternatively it makes the individual work less when their earnings are raised as they now can "afford" more leisure time. The substitution effect works in the opposite direction (unless one or two of the goods involved are "inferior", but let`s not get into that ;)). When the relative price for leisure is lowered by the lowered hourly earnings, the individual will choose to consume more leisure time and work less. The net effect of these two effects cannot be determined by theory. They can only be observed empiricly. The only thing we can say is that the treshold for start working is raised when the earnings are lowered, and the treshold is lowered when earnings are raised.
 
 In the crime situation, the individual is choosing between two alternate ways to get a pay-check (just like the individual was choosing between leisure time and money in the analiogy above). The same income- and substitution effects apply here. The punishment and the risk for getting caught can be viewed as a tax on the earnings, as it is a percieved direct cost of the action. The same income and substitution effects apply to the choice between honest work and criminal activity as they did on the choice between leisure time and working.
 
 I`m not saying that this model will predict a rise in criminal activity if punishments are harsher. But I`m saying that the model presents a theoretic possibility for it to happen. Coupled with the other posters points (like Daewos point about "having nothing to loose" and the DOJ study) gives weight to the argument that criminal activity could be expected to rise if we where to implement draconian measures in attempts to stop it.
 
 I hope I made my position on the issue a bit more clear (I know I have a tendancy to muddle things) :)
 
 Oh, and LT also brought up a very interesting point. And that is that the cost for commiting crime can be considered regressive (the cost for making one aditional criminal activity becomes less and less for each crime you commit). By increasing the cost by implementing more draconian punishments, you make the cost even more regressive. And regressive costs on activities (lika a regressive tax) naturally encourages more of that behaviour.
